awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Harness the Big Data via Large-Scale Lifelong Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in big data infrastructures and algorithm foundations have unleashed a torrent of data being collected and stored in distributed data centers all over the world. The ever-increasing availability of these massive datasets leads to many machine learning tasks that are inherently related. Therefore transfer learning paradigms have been developed in the past decade to perform knowledge transfer among tasks to improve their generalization performance. This project will develop a suite of large-scale lifelong learning methods to address significant challenges from knowledge transfer on big data. The algorithms and tools developed in this project will directly impact biomedical informatics and intelligent transportation systems, as they will be used to build personalized predictive models from electronic medical records and traffic state models from big traffic data. The success of this project will be used to develop a new curriculum that incorporates research into the classroom and provides students from under-represented groups with opportunities to participate in machine learning research. 

The properties of velocity, volume, variability, and variety that characterize big data have imposed significant challenges in the traditional lifelong learning approaches. This project will advance lifelong learning by (1) developing a distributed life-long learning framework to enable online knowledge transfer on large-scale distributed datasets; (2) designing effective methods to track temporal drifting in the task relationship, and leverage human knowledge via interactive transfer; and (3) investigating strategies that enable the distributed life-long learning to handle heterogeneities from both feature spaces and learning tasks. The results of this project will have an immediate and strong impact on Big Data theoretical and algorithmic foundations, by enabling a large-scale lifelong learning framework readily available for many Big Data analytics. All findings, publications, software, and data will be made publicly available at the project website: http://jiayuzhou.github.io/projects/career.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has significantly advanced the development of scalable lifelong learning methods tailored to meet the computational demands of big data. This research has pioneered breakthroughs in distributed, dynamic, and heterogeneous learning, enabling machine learning techniques to effectively handle the complexities of non-IID data, multimodal inputs, and resource-constrained environments. Notable achievements include the development of robust federated learning algorithms with theoretical guarantees of linear speedup, innovative digital biomarkers for early cognitive impairment detection, and adaptive frameworks to address the unique challenges of biomedical data integration. Additionally, the project has made strides in securing machine learning models through novel adversarial robustness and backdoor mitigation strategies, demonstrating their application in real-world settings like healthcare and privacy-sensitive domains. These outcomes have collectively advanced the frontiers of machine learning, ensuring that computational techniques align with the diverse, evolving nature of big data.

The project has also had a profound broader impact by seamlessly integrating lifelong learning principles into education and outreach initiatives, thereby fostering a new generation of skilled researchers and practitioners. Undergraduate and graduate curricula were enriched with real-world problem-solving experiences based on project findings, empowering students with cutting-edge knowledge in machine learning and big data. The project also engaged high school students in interdisciplinary research, encouraging early involvement in STEM fields. Beyond academia, the dissemination of research findings through open-source contributions, international workshops, and high-impact publications has fostered collaborative advancements in healthcare, data privacy, and federated learning. These efforts have not only democratized access to powerful machine learning tools but also addressed critical societal challenges, such as creating scalable, cost-effective healthcare diagnostics, ensuring privacy-preserving data analysis, and promoting fairness in decision-making algorithms.
